thread.title: Liverpool's season is already over despite Tottenham win, says Alan Shearer
thread.title_full: Liverpool's season is already over despite Tottenham win, says Alan Shearer

author: Joe Mewis
title: Liverpool's season is already over despite Tottenham win, says Alan Shearer
text:
Liverpool's season is already over despite Tottenham win, says Alan Shearer Jurgen Klopp's side are out of both the cups and 11 points behind Premier League leaders Chelsea Share Shearer believes that Liverpool's season is done and dusted (Photo: Getty/BBC) Share Get Liverpool FC updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Liverpool's win over Tottenham is not enough to save their season, says Alan Shearer. 
Jurgen Klopp's side won their first Premier League game of 2017 when they claimed a convincing 2-0 win over Spurs thanks to a quickfire Sadio Mane brace at Anfield. 
That ended a run of four losses in five games and saw the Reds climb back into the Champions League qualification places, where they sit in fourth place, 11 points adrift of leaders Chelsea. 
And while former Blackburn and Newcastle striker Shearer admits the Reds put in an excellent performance against Spurs, their hopes of challenging Antonio Conte's pace-setters for the title are over. 
And with Klopp's men out of both domestic cups, he believes that their campaign is over. The Reds impressed in the 2-0 win over Spurs (Photo: Getty for Tottenham Hotspur) 
"No matter what happens from here on in, it will just be one of those seasons when they have once more knocked on the door but not stepped over the threshold," he writes in the Sun . 
"Their league campaign has faltered because they have not always taken the opposition seriously enough, too. 
"They can get up for the big games but Saturday was their first win in six in the league. Second-placed Spurs were seemingly no problem. They also drew with table-toppers Chelsea. 
"But Hull, Sunderland and Swansea in that recent run were another matter." Mane netted twice to see of Pochettino's men (Photo: Andrew Powell) Read More 10 things we learned this Premier League weekend 
And unlike some pundits, Shearer doesn't believe that Klopp's high-pressing style of football is to blame for their recent slump. 
"I donâ€™t buy that at all," he continues. "The players should be fit enough to cope with that. Without midweek European football, they had a great chance this season but have not taken it." 
Prior to their win over Spurs, Klopp urged his side to win every single one of their 14 remaining games. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
